Parser

Class Parser

  • java.lang.Object
    • Parser.Parser

  • public class Parser
extends java.lang.Object
    Class to parse the String
    Author:
    Jan-Willem Gmelig Meyling

    • Nested Class Summary

      private class  Parser.Reference
      These split methods needs some shared variables, and are placed in a inner class for this purpose.

    • Field Detail

      • input

        private final java.lang.String input
        A final variable to store the String that is being parsed.

      • length

        private final int length
        An final int to store the length of the input String.

      • sheet

        private final Sheet sheet
        A variable to store the current Sheet, so Cell and Range types can be accessed.

      • index

        private int index
        An int to store the current index. Because we increment the value in the next method, we start at -1 so the value always matches the current index.

      • current

        private char current
        A char to store the current character.

      • depth

        private int depth
        A value to store the current depth in brackets. Used to determine which closing bracket closes to the first opening bracket. When we go one level of parentheses deeper, this value increments, allowing to ignore data between the parentheses and parse these recursively instead.

      • openBracket

        private int openBracket
        A value to store the index of the open bracket we're working on. Used to split function arguments and to recursively call the new parser on a substring.

      • closeBracket

        private int closeBracket
        A value to store the index of the bracket that closes the first open bracket. Used to split function arguments and to recursively call the new parser on a substring.

      • isNegative

        private boolean isNegative
        A value to store whether a Number or Function -output should be converted to it's negative value.

      • function

        private Function function
        A variable to store the function currently being parsed. This value should be null when no function is being parsed, so expressions - which require different behaviour of the parentheses - are parsed correctly.

      • arguments

        java.util.List<java.lang.Object> arguments
        This list is used to store the function arguments.

      • values

        java.util.Stack<java.lang.Object> values
        This stack is used for pushing and popping values.

      • operators

        java.util.Stack<Operator> operators
        This stack is used for pushing and popping operators.

      • SECOND_OPERATOR_CHARACTERS

        private static final java.lang.String SECOND_OPERATOR_CHARACTERS
        These characters are the allowed characters for the operators that take two characters (for example the >= operator)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • Parser

        private Parser(Parser parser,
      int from,
      int to)
        Private Parse constructor. Used for recursive parsing between parentheses.
        Parameters:

        from - From index
        to - To index

    • Method Detail

      • parse

        public java.lang.Object parse()
        Public parse method. Initiates the parsing of the current instance, and returns the result.
        Returns:
        Result in the type of Integer, Double, Boolean or String
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If a undefined Function or Operator was called.
        java.lang.NumberFormatException - If the string does not contain a parsable number.

      • openBracket

        private void openBracket()
        When a bracket is opened, the depth of this Parser instance is incremented. If the depth equals 1, then set the openBracket value to the current index, so that we keep this value for later use.

      • closeBracket

        private void closeBracket()
        When a bracket is closed, the depth of this Parser instance is decremented. If the depth now equals 0 - and thus all opened brackets are closed - we push the calculated value to the value stack. If the value is a Function result, fetch the arguments first and calculate the value.
        Authors:
        • Jan-Willem Gmelig Meyling

      • calculate

        private void calculate()
        To calculate a value, pop two value objects from the value stack, and one Operator from the operator stack. Then calculate the value, for the operation of the operator with the two arguments, and push the result to the value stack.
        Throws:
        EmptyStackException - if this value stack or operator stack is empty.
        Authors:
        • Jan-Willem Gmelig Meyling

      • pushOperator

        private void pushOperator(Operator operator)
        This method pushes an Operator to the operator stack. When the operator stack isn't empty, we peek for the last Operator. If the precedence of the Operator in the stack is higher than or equal to the precedence of the Operator supplied as argument, we calculate this value first. 
         This is such that 5 * 5 + 5 converts to 25 + 5.
        See also Dijkstra's Two Stack algorithm.
        Parameters:
        operator - The operator to push
        Authors:
        • Jan-Willem Gmelig Meyling

      • argumentSeparator

        private void argumentSeparator()
        Create a new argument separator

      • getNumber

        private java.lang.Number getNumber()
                            throws java.lang.NumberFormatException
        Method to parse a Number from the input string.
        Returns:
        a Number object holding the value represented by the String-argument.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NumberFormatException - if the string does not contain a parsable number.

      • getOperator

        private void getOperator()
        Method to peek for an operator at the current position in the String.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if no such Operator is implemented

      • getFunction

        private void getFunction()
        Method to peek for a function at the current position in the String.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified enum type has no constant with the specified name, or the specified class object does not represent an enum type

      • hasNext

        boolean hasNext()
        Method to determine if there is a next character
        Returns:
        true if there is a next character

      • next

        char next()
        Return the next character in the String, and increment the current index.
        Returns:
        next character

      • peek

        char peek(int n)
        Peek for the next n-character. This is useful for parsing elements of which you can't be sure what type it is. For instance, 'A' can mean: the start of Function ADD(), or the Reference to Cell A1.
        Parameters:
        n - Amount of characters to peek forward
        Returns:
        The character at the given index

      • increment

        void increment(int n)
        Increment the index with a given value. This is useful when the current index needs to be changed after a peek.
        Parameters:
        n - Amount to increment index with.

      • previous

        char previous()
        Get the previous character in the String.
        Returns:
        The previous character, or 0 if the current index is 0.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • parse

        public static java.lang.Object parse(Sheet sheet,
                     java.lang.String string)
        Static method to initiate parsing of an expression. Automatically slices of the '=' character at the beginning, and removes spaces.
        Parameters:
        string - Input
        Returns:
        The result of the parse, which can be of various types. When the input String did not start with a = character, the original String is returned.

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Run and type!
        Parameters:
        args -
